verified_isomorphisms.canonical_form: Hybrid quantum-classical optimization for combinatorial graph problems

paper1.title: Quantum Reinforcement Learning with Transformers for the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem
paper1.abstract_excerpt: hybrid quantum-classical reinforcement learning models for addressing complex combinatorial optimization problems such as the CVRP

paper2.title: Accelerating De Novo Genome Assembly via Quantum-Assisted Graph Optimization with Bitstring Recovery
paper2.abstract_excerpt: hybrid approach utilizing a quantum computing-based optimization algorithm integrated with classical pre-processing to expedite the genome assembly process

verified_isomorphisms.why_excellent: IDENTICAL ALGORITHM STRUCTURE: Both use quantum annealing combined with classical preprocessing to solve combinatorial graph optimization problems. The only difference is the application domain (vehicle routing vs genome assembly). This is a textbook cross-domain isomorphism - same method, different problem.
verified_isomorphisms.value: Demonstrates that quantum-classical hybrid optimization is a genuinely portable mechanism across domains. Researchers in logistics and genomics independently arrived at the same solution structure.

verified_isomorphisms.canonical_form: Neural network scaling laws relating performance to model parameters/data size

paper1.title: Optimal scaling laws in learning hierarchical multi-index models
paper1.abstract_excerpt: sharp theory of scaling laws for two-layer neural networks trained on a class of hierarchical multi-index targets, in a genuinely representation-limited regime

paper2.title: Broken neural scaling laws in materials science
paper2.abstract_excerpt: study two multi-objective graph neural networks trained to predict the frequency-dependent complex interband dielectric function... observe broken neural scaling laws with respect to dataset size

verified_isomorphisms.why_excellent: SAME THEORETICAL FRAMEWORK: Both study neural network scaling laws - how performance scales with data and parameters. One develops theory, the other applies it to materials science and discovers 'broken' scaling. This is theory meeting application across domains.
verified_isomorphisms.value: Shows scaling laws are a universal phenomenon in neural networks, appearing in both theoretical statistics and applied materials science. The 'broken' scaling discovery in materials science validates and extends the theoretical framework.

verified_isomorphisms.canonical_form: Γ-convergence and spectral methods for analyzing system stability and transitions

paper1.title: Metastable Transitions and Γ-Convergent Eyring-Kramers Asymptotics in Landau-QCD Gradient Systems
paper1.abstract_excerpt: combining variational methods, Γ- and Mosco convergence, and spectral perturbation theory, we establish the persistence and stability of local minima and index-one saddles

paper2.title: Spectral Theory for Borel PMP Graphs
paper2.abstract_excerpt: show that the spectrum is continuous under local-global convergence

verified_isomorphisms.why_excellent: SHARED MATHEMATICAL MACHINERY: Both use advanced convergence theory (Γ-convergence, spectral convergence) to analyze stability and transitions in different systems. One applies to physical systems (quantum field theory), the other to graph structures. The mathematical framework is identical.
verified_isomorphisms.value: Demonstrates that convergence theory provides a unifying mathematical bridge between physics and pure mathematics. Same theoretical tools, different objects of study.

papers: Limitations of SGD for Multi-Index Models
good_isomorphisms.why_good: Both examine neural network architectures and their computational properties. Strong technical connection but broader than 'excellent' matches.

papers: Inverse Depth Scaling From Most Layers Being Similar
Broken neural scaling laws in materials science
good_isomorphisms.why_good: Both study scaling behaviors in neural networks. Depth scaling meets parameter scaling.

papers: Hydrodynamics and structure formation in magnetic fluids
good_isomorphisms.why_good: Both study emergence of structured patterns - latent representations in neural networks vs physical aggregates in fluids. Different substrates, same phenomenon.
Both analyze strategic positioning and decision-making. Political messaging strategy meets financial market strategy.

papers: Condition-Dependent Source Distribution for Flow Matching
Confidence Estimation for Deep CT Reconstruction
good_isomorphisms.why_good: Both use diffusion-based generative models. Same technical framework, different applications.

papers: Biologically-inspired foveated interface for vision models
good_isomorphisms.why_good: Biological adaptation (foveation) inspires AI parameter adaptation (LoRA). Bio-inspired AI connection.

papers: Masked Discrete Diffusion for Single-Cell Modeling
false_positives_to_avoid.why_false_positive: Word 'diffusion' has different meanings: generative diffusion models vs heat diffusion. No structural similarity.
false_positives_to_avoid.lesson: Context matters - same word, different mechanisms. Need to distinguish diffusion_generative from diffusion_physical.

false_positives_to_avoid.why_false_positive: Both mention 'optimization' but use completely different mathematical frameworks. Generic term overlap.
false_positives_to_avoid.lesson: Generic 'optimization' without specific method is too broad. Need to identify the optimization algorithm/approach.

ambiguous_terms_causing_false_positives: evolution (evolutionary algorithms vs biological evolution vs system dynamics)
network (neural networks vs social networks vs graph structures)

metadata.notes: These verified isomorphisms serve as templates for improving matching logic. Excellent matches show what we're looking for - shared structure, not just shared vocabulary.
